bib.title: Learning to lurker rank: An evaluation of learning-to-rank methods for lurking behavior analysis
bib.author: Diego Perna and Roberto Interdonato and Andrea Tagarelli
bib.abstract: While being long researched in social science and computer–human interaction, lurking behaviors in online social networks (OSNs) have been computationally studied only in recent years. Remarkably, determining lurking behaviors has been modeled as an unsupervised, eigenvector-centrality-based ranking problem, and it has been shown that lurkers can effectively be ranked according to the link structure of an OSN graph. Although this approach has enabled researchers to overcome the lack of ground-truth data at a large scale, the complexity of the problem hints at the opportunity of learning from past lurking experiences as well as of using a variety of behavioral features, including any available, possibly platform-specific information on the activity and interaction of lurkers in an OSN.
